strings.Value: "I'm glad you were able to forgive your tribe."
"You shouldn't have killed the old man. None of this was his fault."
"You shouldn't have spared the old man."
"Why the long face? You got revenge on Janush AND your tribe! You won!"
{n}Regongar looks at the city below, dazed.{/n} "Well, it's over. No accusations, no spitting in their faces, no big fight... just a pile of scorched bones and some stupid story from an old fart."

"It's a shame I couldn't meet my brother, of course, but he's in {g|Pharasma}Pharasma's{/g} hands now, just like the rest of them. Buried and... Well, no, not forgotten. I'll remember this. Just... left behind. I don't waste time looking for lessons in everything like Linzi does, but if any conclusion can be drawn from this story, it's this — let's not screw our lives like these pieces of shit did."

"Really, I'm not even sure what I was expecting. Life's just a long, feeble joke, and most end up being the punchline rather than laughing at it. I have to let it go. So I have no tribe — so what? I have you, and Octavia, and the rest of our crazy gang."

"Here's the plan, then — we keep having fun together till the end. And when our time comes, we go out with a blast! Anyone doesn't like it — well, they can burn, heh heh heh!" {n}The half-orc's flashes his sharp teeth in a broad grin.{/n}
"You're my tribe. You. Octavia. The rest of our crazy gang. And I don't need anybody else."

"Forgive them? Hells no! I haven't forgiven anyone — not them, and not Janush! But who cares how I treat them in my head, anyway? There are some things in life you can't change. It's stupid to sit and howl about them like a wolf howling at the moon, that's all."

"Guilty or not — what difference does it make? My father and the rest of the tribe eluded me. I had to take it out on someone, and this old geezer was the only one left. What, you feel sorry for him, or something?"
"Ah, let him be. I'm not going to judge every stupid dog that bites someone in the wastelands. Besides, it looks like nature's punished the old geezer enough already!"
"Didn't I, though? You could say we... bumped him off as part of a speedy trial. A military field trial, right? Heh heh!"
"He's not worth it. Did you even see that dung-chafer? What was I to do, get revenge on some ancient fart in place of my father? I could barely stand looking at him. Forget that."

"Heh heh... Yeah, I won. I guess. But I feel like I just ate a pile of shit. That old geezer's head was a poor substitute for my father's — doesn't feel like much of a victory... But whatever, don't sweat it. I shouldn't be whining. A shitty victory is still a victory!"
